# Rigor mortis

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

This article is about the sign of death. For other uses, see [Rigor mortis
(disambiguation)](/wiki/Rigor_mortis_\(disambiguation\) "Rigor mortis
\(disambiguation\)").

**Rigor mortis** ([Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin"): _rigor_ "stiffness", _mortis_
"of death") or **postmortem rigidity** , the third [stage of
death](/wiki/Stages_of_death "Stages of death"), is one of the recognizable
[signs of death](/wiki/Signs_of_death#Signs "Signs of death"), caused by
chemical changes in the [muscles](/wiki/Muscle "Muscle") post mortem, which
cause the limbs of the [corpse](/wiki/Cadaver "Cadaver") to stiffen.[1] In
humans, rigor mortis can occur as soon as 4 hours post mortem.

## Contents

  * 1 Physiology
  * 2 Physical changes
  * 3 Applications in meat industry
  * 4 Application in forensic pathology
  * 5 See also
  * 6 References
  * 7 Bibliography

## Physiology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rigor_mortis&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Physiology")]

After death, respiration in an organism ceases, depleting the source of oxygen
used in the making of **[adenosine triphosphate](/wiki/Adenosine_triphosphate
"Adenosine triphosphate")** (ATP). ATP is required to cause separation of the
[actin-myosin](/wiki/Myofibril "Myofibril") [cross-
bridges](/wiki/Sliding_filament_theory "Sliding filament theory") during
relaxation of muscle.[2] When oxygen is no longer present, the body may
continue to produce ATP via anaerobic [glycolysis](/wiki/Glycolysis
"Glycolysis"). When the body's [glycogen](/wiki/Glycogen "Glycogen") is
depleted, the ATP concentration diminishes, and the body enters rigor mortis
because it is unable to break those bridges.[3]

Additionally, calcium enters the [cytosol](/wiki/Cytosol "Cytosol") after
death. Calcium is released into the cytosol due to the deterioration of the
[sarcoplasmic reticulum](/wiki/Sarcoplasmic_reticulum "Sarcoplasmic
reticulum"). Also, the breakdown of the sarcolemma causes additional calcium
to enter the cytosol. The calcium activates the formation of actin-myosin
cross-bridging. Once calcium is introduced into the cytosol, it binds to the
troponin of thin filaments, which causes the troponin-tropomyosin complex to
change shape and allow the myosin heads to bind to the active sites of actin
proteins.[1] In rigor mortis [myosin](/wiki/Myosin "Myosin") heads continue
binding with the active sites of actin proteins via [adenosine
diphosphate](/wiki/Adenosine_diphosphate "Adenosine diphosphate") (ADP), and
the muscle is unable to relax until further enzyme activity degrades the
complex.[2]

Normal relaxation would occur by replacing ADP with ATP, which would
destabilize the myosin-actin bond and break the cross-bridge.[1] However, as
ATP is absent, there must be a breakdown of muscle
[tissue](/wiki/Tissue_\(biology\) "Tissue \(biology\)") by
[enzymes](/wiki/Enzyme "Enzyme") (endogenous or bacterial) during
[decomposition](/wiki/Decomposition "Decomposition"). As part of the process
of decomposition, the myosin heads are degraded by the enzymes, allowing the
muscle contraction to release and the body to relax.[4][5] Decomposition of
the myofilaments occurs 48 to 60 hours after the peak of rigor mortis, which
occurs approximately 13 hours after death.[1]

## Physical
changes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rigor_mortis&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Physical changes")]

At the time of death, a condition called "primary flaccidity" occurs.
Following this, the muscles stiffen in rigor mortis. All muscles in the body
are affected. Starting between two and six hours following death, rigor mortis
begins with the eyelids, neck, and jaw. The sequence may be due to different
[lactic acid](/wiki/Lactic_acid "Lactic acid") levels among different muscles,
which is directly related to the difference in [glycogen](/wiki/Glycogen
"Glycogen") levels and different types of muscle fibers.

Rigor mortis then spreads to the other muscles, including the internal organs,
within the next four to six hours. The onset of rigor mortis is affected by
the individual's age, sex, physical condition, and muscular build. Rigor
mortis may not be perceivable in many infant and child corpses due to their
smaller muscle mass.[6]

## Applications in meat
industry[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rigor_mortis&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Applications in meat industry")]

Rigor mortis is very important in meat technology. The onset of rigor mortis
and its resolution partially determine the tenderness of [meat](/wiki/Meat
"Meat"). If the post-slaughter meat is immediately chilled to 15 °C (59 °F), a
phenomenon known as cold shortening occurs, whereby the muscle sarcomeres
shrink to a third of their original length.

Cold shortening is caused by the release of stored [calcium](/wiki/Calcium
"Calcium") ions from the [sarcoplasmic reticulum](/wiki/Sarcoplasmic_reticulum
"Sarcoplasmic reticulum") of muscle fibers, in response to the cold stimulus.
The calcium ions trigger powerful muscle contraction aided by ATP molecules.
To prevent cold shortening, a process known as electrical stimulation is
carried out, especially in beef carcasses, immediately after
[slaughter](/wiki/Animal_slaughter "Animal slaughter") and
[skinning](/wiki/Skinning "Skinning"). In this process, the
[carcass](/wiki/Cadaver "Cadaver") is stimulated with [alternating
current](/wiki/Alternating_current "Alternating current"), causing it to
contract and relax, which depletes the ATP reserve from the carcass and
prevents cold shortening.[7]

## Application in forensic
pathology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rigor_mortis&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Application in forensic pathology")]

The degree of rigor mortis may be used in [forensic
pathology](/wiki/Forensic_pathology "Forensic pathology"), to determine the
approximate time of death. A dead body holds its position as rigor mortis sets
in. If the body is moved after death, but before rigor mortis begins, forensic
techniques such as [livor mortis](/wiki/Livor_mortis "Livor mortis") can be
applied. If the position in which a body is found does not match the location
where it is found (for example, if it is flat on its back with one arm
sticking straight up), that could mean someone moved it.

Several factors also affect the progression of rigor mortis, and investigators
take these into account when estimating the time of death. One such factor is
the ambient temperature. In warm environments, the onset and pace of rigor
mortis are sped up by providing a conducive environment for the metabolic
processes that cause decay. Low temperatures, however, slow them down.
Therefore, for a person who dies outside in frozen conditions rigor mortis may
last several days more than normal, so investigators may have to abandon it as
a tool for determining time of death.[8][9]
